column1: The change at the school was very speedily made. The squire generally carried out his resolutions while they were hot and
column2: on the very day after his conversation with his wife on the subject
column3: he went first to the vicar and arranged for the retirement of the clerk
column4: and the instalment of White in his place; and then went to the school house
column5: and informed the master of his intention. The latter had been expecting his dismissal
column6: since Mrs. Ellison had spoken to him on the previous day; and the news which the squire gave him was a relief to him. His emoluments
column8: would be smaller than those he received as schoolmaster; but while he would not be able to discharge the duties of the latter for very much longer
column9: for he felt the boys were getting too much for him
column10: he would be able to perform the very easy work entailed by the clerkship for many years to come. It was
column12: a position not without dignity; and indeed
column13: in the eyes of the village the clerk was a personage of far greater importance than the schoolmaster.
